page.title: 14HOME LIFE DARTMOOR FARM
page.content: The churchwarden farmed at Elliot's Hill until he handed over to his son.He now lives on the farm in a cottage which he built himself and called New Glebe House.He gave it this name because he used stones from the ruins of a thirteenth century priest's house on the glebeland which was part of his farm. The stone built open fire in his living room has a lintel which came from the fire in the pheasant keeper's house, now also a ruin.In the garden is the iron pump and a stone trough marked E.R.P.B.These were both in the kitchen of the old farmhouse.The water from the well is now pumped by electricity. On the farm a barn has been converted into an art studio for Jayne Mayhew.She specialises in painting pictures from photos of moorland scenes.She uses oil, water colour,&ink
